raw_text:
Trial date is set for Balco case
 
 A US judge has set a preliminary trial date for the Balco steroid distribution case which has rocked athletics.
 
 US district court judge Susan Ilston rejected an attempt by the defence team to have the case dismissed at a pre-trial hearing in San Francisco. And she set a March date for the case of the four men accused of distributing illegal performance-enhancing drugs to elite athletes to be heard. A firm decision on whether the trial takes place is expected in January. The judge said that she may conduct hearings in January into whether federal agents illegally searched the Balco headquarters and wrongfully obtained statements from the company's founder Victor Conte and its vice-president James Valente. The two men - along with personal trainer Greg Anderson and athletics coach Remy Korchemny - were all indicted earlier this year but have pleaded their innocence. The outcome of those hearings could result in some or all of the charges being dismissed. Conte said that he would be telling his side of the story on an American TV show on Friday.
 
 "The world deserves to know the truth about performance-enhancing drugs," he said. Balco (The Bay Area Laboratory Cooperative) is the company at the centre of the scandal. The company has been accused by the United States Anti-Doping Agency (USADA) of being the source of the banned steroid THG and modafinil. The USADA claims that 10 athletes have received sanctions for testing positive for THG and modafinil. Former double world champion Kelli White and Olympic relay star Alvin Harrison have both been banned on the basis of materials discovered during the Balco investigation. Britain's former European 100m champion Dwain Chambers is currently serving a two-year ban after testing positive for THG in an out-of-competition test in 2003.
llama3.2:1b: A US judge has set a trial date for the Balco steroid distribution case, with April 20th as the preliminary trial date. The case will consider charges against four men accused of distributing illegal performance-enhancing drugs to elite athletes. A US district court judge rejected an attempt to dismiss the case at a pre-trial hearing in San Francisco and set a March date for trials of four individuals accused of distribution.
llama3.2:3b: A US judge has set a March trial date for the Balco steroid distribution case, rejecting the defense's attempt to dismiss it. The trial will feature four men accused of distributing performance-enhancing drugs to elite athletes, including company founder Victor Conte and coach Remy Korchemny. The outcome of hearings in January could result in some charges being dismissed if federal agents are found to have illegally searched the company or wrongfully obtained statements from its founders.
gemma2:2b: A US judge set a March trial date for the Balco steroid distribution case, with further hearings possible to determine if federal agents violated rules during their investigation and whether charges should be dropped.  The four men accused of distributing illegal performance-enhancing drugs (Victor Conte, James Valente, Greg Anderson, and Remy Korchemny) have pleaded not guilty. The outcome of any such hearing could result in the dismissal of some or all charges.
qwen2.5:0.5b: US judge set preliminary trial date for BALCO steroid distribution case, with expected hearing March 2019.
qwen2.5:1.5b: A US court has set March as the preliminary trial date for the Balco steroid distribution case, involving four men accused of distributing illegal performance-enhancing drugs to athletes. Federal agents are being investigated over a search at Balco headquarters and alleged violations of law. The judge will also review whether hearings should be conducted into these matters in January. Conte claims he will tell his side of the story on an upcoming TV show.
qwen2.5:3b: A US judge has set a March preliminary trial date for the Balco steroid distribution case involving four men accused of distributing illegal performance-enhancing drugs to elite athletes. The case, which includes accusations against former personal trainer Greg Anderson and athletics coach Remy Korchemny, may face further hearings in January regarding potential violations by federal agents. USADA claims THG and modafinil originated from Balco, leading to bans for several athletes including Kelli White, Alvin Harrison, and Dwain Chambers. The judge rejected an attempt to dismiss the case at a pre-trial hearing.

The outcome of those hearings could result in some or all charges being dismissed, with the court expected to announce a decision by January 2016.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
A US federal judge, Susan Ilston, has scheduled a preliminary trial for the Balco steroid distribution case, involving four men accused of illegally distributing performance-enhancing drugs to elite athletes. The trial is set to begin in March. The defendants—Victor Conte, James Valente, Greg Anderson, and Remy Korchemny—have pleaded not guilty. In January, the judge indicated potential hearings to determine if federal agents illegally searched Balco's headquarters and obtained incriminating statements from its founders, which could lead to charge dismissals.

Balco, located in the Bay Area, is under investigation by the US Anti-Doping Agency (USADA) for allegedly supplying banned steroid THG and modafinil to 10 athletes. Notable affected athletes include Kelli White, Alvin Harrison, and Dwain Chambers, who has served a two-year ban for testing positive for THG in 2003. Conte plans to share his account on an American TV show. The court's ruling in January will significantly impact the case's progression.

Judge Susan Ilston rejected a defense attempt to dismiss the case and may hold hearings on whether federal agents conducted illegal searches and obtained wrongful statements. The four accused—Victor Conte, James Valente, Greg Anderson, and Remy Korchemny—have pleaded innocence. Balco is accused of distributing banned steroids THG and modafinil, with USADA linking the company to doping violations. Several athletes, including Kelli White, Alvin Harrison, and Dwain Chambers, have faced bans due to the investigation. Conte plans to share his side of the story on television.
